document.masterDocTitle: A taxonomic review of the Crypticerya species (Hemiptera: Coccoidea: Monophlebidae) of the southwestern United States and Mexico, including description of a new species from Baja California

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A taxonomic review of the Crypticerya species (Hemiptera: Coccoidea: Monophlebidae) of the southwestern United States and Mexico, including description of a new species from Baja California

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description of adult female (based on lectotypes of
I. littoralis mimosae
,
I. littoralis tonilensis
,
I. ( Proticerya ) littoralis
and 6 paralectotypes of
I. ( Proticerya ) littoralis
).

Slide-mounted specimens. Body elliptical, 3.9â5.4 mm long, 2.3â3.8 mm wide ( lectotype of
I. ( Proticerya ) littoralis
5.4 mm long, 3.8 mm wide; lectotype of
I. littoralis mimosae
5.1 mm long, 3.3 mm wide; lectotype of
I. littoralis tonilensis
3.9 mm long, 2.3 mm wide). Antennae (
Fig. 5
A) 9 segmented, apical segment 150â200 Âµm long, 70â90 Âµm wide; hair-like setae on apical segment up to 550 Âµm long. Eyes 90â110 Âµm wide. Clypeolabral shield 430â500 Âµm long, 325â475 Âµm wide, labium 260â315 Âµm long, 200â325 Âµm wide. Hindlegs (
Fig. 5
J)
1725â1905
Âµm long; trochanter+femur 640â740 Âµm long, tibia+tarsus 780â880 Âµm long; setae on leg segments 40â105 Âµm long; distal trochanteral setae 175â300 Âµm long; claw digitules 20â38 Âµm long. Mesothoracic spiracles each 155â190 Âµm long, atrium 105â140 Âµm wide; metathoracic spiracles each 205â275 Âµm long, atrium 145â185 Âµm wide; derm at atrial opening with 3â6 simple multilocular pores, 10â 11 Âµm in diameter with bilocular centre and 9â12 outer loculi. Ovisac band present, formed by dense setae 75â100 Âµm long, with round to flattened bases (
Fig. 5
H) and multilocular pores of two types : (i) larger pores (
Fig. 5
G, I) forming inner band, 7â9 pores wide, each pore 11â13 Âµm in diameter, with bilocular or trilocular centre and 6â12 outer loculi, and (ii) smaller pores (
Fig. 5
E, F) forming outer band 3â5 pores wide, each pore 9â10 Âµm in diameter, with bilocular centre and 3â8 outer loculi, appearing slightly bluish when stained. Vulvar opening as for genus, surrounded by typical multilocular pores (
Fig. 5
K), each 12â13 Âµm in diameter. Cicatrices oval to round, numbering 3 ; central cicatrix 160â235 Âµm long, 90â155 Âµm wide, lateral cicatrices 110â 220 Âµm long, 90â125 Âµm wide. Abdominal spiracles (
Fig. 5
M) with atrium 23â35 Âµm wide; multilocular pores (
Fig. 5
G, I) each 11â12 Âµm in diameter, with bilocular or trilocular centre and 6â9 outer loculi, clustered on derm surrounding opening. Anal ring 105â190 Âµm wide; anal opening surrounded by hair-like setae 138â 225 Âµm long and typical multilocular pores (
Fig. 5
L), each 11â12 Âµm in diameter.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Crypticerya littoralis
adult Î¨. A. Antenna; B. Simple multilocular pore with bilocular centre and five outer loculi; C. Simple multilocular pore with trilocular centre and three outer loculi; D. Flagellate seta; E. Simple multilocular pore, similar to vulvar pore, with bilocular centre and six outer loculi; F. Simple multilocular pore, similar to vulvar pore, with bilocular centre and five outer loculi; G. Simple multilocular pore with bilocular centre and nine outer loculi; H. Flagellate seta present in ovisac band; I. Simple multilocular pore with trilocular centre and eight outer loculi; J. Hindleg; K. Vulvar multilocular pore; L. Anal multilocular pore; M. Abdominal spiracle; N. Simple multilocular pore with bilocular centre and seven outer loculi; O. Short hair-like seta; P. Long hair-like seta.

FIGURE 6.
Crypticerya littoralis
first-instar nymph. A. Flagellate seta; B. Simple multilocular pore with bilocular centre and four outer loculi; C. Abdominal spiracle; D. Anal tube; E. Long hair-like seta; F. Simple multilocular pore with bilocular centre and seven outer loculi.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Dorsum. Hair-like setae (
Fig. 5
O ), 50â300 Âµm long, sparsely scattered; longest setae (
Fig. 5
P), 325â450 Âµm long, forming marginal clusters on each segment. Flagellate setae (
Fig. 5
D), 35â50 Âµm long, distributed as for genus. Simple multilocular pores (
Fig. 5
G, I), each 12â13 Âµm in diameter, with bilocular or trilocular centre, forming medial longitudinal row on head and thorax; similar pores (
Fig. 5
N), each 10â11 Âµm in diameter, with bilocular centre (less often trilocular) and 6â8 outer loculi, scattered on rest of derm.

Venter. Hair-like setae (
Fig. 5
O ), 75â250 Âµm long, scattered medially to submedially across head and thorax; longest setae (
Fig. 5
P), 300â425 Âµm long, clustered between antennae. Flagellate setae (
Fig. 5
D), 35â50 Âµm long, distributed as for genus. Simple multilocular pores (
Fig. 5
G, I), each 10â12 Âµm in diameter, with bilocular or trilocular centre and 6â9 outer loculi, forming marginal clusters on all body segments and scattered on margins and submargins of head, thorax and abdomen. Multilocular pores (
Fig. 5
B, C), each 11â12 Âµm in diameter, with bilocular or trilocular centre and 2â5 outer loculi, scattered medially to submedially on head and thorax; similar pores (
Fig. 5
B), each 12â13 Âµm in diameter, with bilocular centre and 4â6 outer loculi, scattered medially to submedially across abdomen.

Description of first-instar nymph (based on 2 paralectotypes of
I. littoralis mimosae
and 3 paralectotypes of
I. ( Proticerya ) littoralis
)

Slide-mounted specimens. Body elliptical, 590â700 Âµm long, 350â400 Âµm wide. Antennae 375â450 Âµm long, apical segment 150â155 Âµm long, 50â60 Âµm wide; hair-like setae on apical segment up to 550 Âµm long. Eyes 45 Âµm wide. Clypeolabral shield 190 Âµm long, 155 Âµm wide. Hindlegs 648â678 Âµm long; trochanter+femur 200â213 Âµm long, tibia+tarsus 325â363 Âµm long; setae on legs 50â125 Âµm long; distal trochanteral setae 115 Âµm long; claw digitules 43â45 Âµm long. Thoracic spiracles each 38â53 Âµm long; atrium 28â30 Âµm wide. Cicatrix round, 13â18 Âµm in diameter. Abdominal spiracles (
Fig. 6
C) as for genus. Anal tube (
Fig. 6
D) 75â88 Âµm long, 30â33 Âµm wide at opening; multilocular pores inside anal tube 5â6 Âµm in diameter.

Dorsum. Shape and distribution of pores as for genus, except each abdominal segment with one submarginal pore, two submedial pores and one medial pore, and head and thorax with dense multilocular pores. Distribution of hair-like setae (
Fig. 6
E) and flagellate setae (
Fig. 6
A) as for genus. Long hair-like setae 43â50 Âµm long; short hair-like setae 22â30 Âµm long; long marginal setae 90â125 Âµm long. Flagellate setae 43â60 Âµm long. Multilocular pores (
Fig. 6
F), each 8â9 Âµm in diameter on head and thorax, 7â8 Âµm in diameter on abdomen.

Venter. Distribution of setae and pores as for genus. Hair-like setae (
Fig. 6
E) 30â45 Âµm long; long hairlike setae 650â900 Âµm long, in three pairs at abdominal apex. Flagellate setae (
Fig. 6
A) 22â25 Âµm long. Multilocular pores (
Fig. 6
B), each 7â8 Âµm in diameter on head and thorax, 6â7 Âµm in diameter on abdomen.

Type data.
Icerya ( Proticerya ) littoralis
: MEXICO , El Faro, near Frontera, âon the sea-beach, on the sandy ridges just beyond the reach of ordinary surfâ, ex Croton [=
Codiaeum
sp.],
16 .v. 1897
( Townsend ).
Icerya littoralis mimosae
: MEXICO , Las Minas, near Frontera, ex "Sarsa" [=
Mimosa
sp.],
4 .vi. 1897
( Townsend ).
Icerya littoralis tonilensis
: MEXICO , Jalisco, Tonila, âon cultivated treeâ,
2 .viii. 1902
( Townsend ).

Type material examined.
Lectotype of
Icerya ( Proticerya ) littoralis
(designated by
Unruh & Gullan, 2008 b
): ad Î¨ ( USNM ). Paralectotypes : 6 ad Î¨Î¨, 6 first-instar nymphs ( USNM ); 2 ad Î¨Î¨ (BME); dry material ( USNM ). Lectotype of
Icerya ( Proticerya ) littoralis mimosae
(designated by
Unruh & Gullan, 2008 b
): ad Î¨ ( USNM ). Paralectotypes : ad Î¨, 12 first-instar nymphs ( UNSM ); dry material ( USNM ). Lectotype of
Icerya littoralis tonilensis
(designated by
Unruh & Gullan, 2008 b
): ad Î¨ ( USNM ). Paralectotypes : dry material ( USNM ).
